query: How does managing semi-natural open habitats with rough grazing compare to using prescribed fire for butterfly and moth populations?
relevant_summary:
Employing areas of semi-natural habitat for rough grazing has shown varied effects on butterfly and moth populations. Two of four studies indicated that grazing led to a higher abundance of large copper butterfly eggs and four out of 13 other butterfly species, but another study found that grazed meadow steppe had a lower abundance of butterflies and moths than ungrazed steppe (3944). One study also found that upland rough grassland managed by livestock grazing had a greater species richness and abundance of butterflies than improved grassland (3944). In contrast, for wetland and pond management, one study found that fens managed by mowing had a greater species richness of butterflies than those managed by cattle grazing (3950).

In studies on prescribed fire, three of four studies in the USA discovered that coniferous forests restored by burning had a higher species richness of butterflies than unburned forests (3877). Two of these studies also found that burned pine forests had a higher abundance of butterflies (3877). However, a study in Australia reported that after selective burning of eucalyptus forest, there were fewer Eltham copper caterpillars than before the fire (3877).

query: What are the benefits for butterflies of maintaining species-rich, semi-natural grasslands compared to using set-aside in European agricultural landscapes?
relevant_summary: Twelve of fifteen studies in Switzerland, the United Kingdom and Sweden found that the species richness or diversity of butterflies and moths on grassland, field margins, wildflower strips or whole farms managed under agri-environment schemes was higher than on conventional fields or farms [3915]. Seventeen of nineteen studies in the UK, Sweden, Switzerland and Germany found that the abundance of butterflies and moths overall, and of specific species of butterflies or moths, in woodland, grassland, field margins, wildflower strips or whole farms managed under agri-environment schemes was higher than in unmanaged woodland or conventional fields or farms [3915]. However, one replicated, site comparison study in Finland found that the species richness of butterflies and day-flying moths on grassland managed under an agri-environment scheme was lower than on abandoned, unmanaged grassland [3915]. Additionally, three studies in Finland and the Czech Republic found that grassland grazed or restored under agri-environment scheme prescriptions had a lower abundance of all but three butterfly and day-flying moth species compared to unmanaged grassland [3915].

query: What factors influence the success of captive breeding and release programs for butterflies and moths?
relevant_summary:
The success of captive breeding and release programs for butterflies and moths is influenced by several factors. Releasing captive-bred individuals has led to populations persisting for 2-28 years and increasing in abundance (3914). However, other studies show populations dying out within 1-12 years, with one review indicating that only 25% of released populations survive for more than three years, and only 8% for more than ten years (3914). Similarly, translocated populations have been reported to persist for between 2 and 49 years, while others have died out in as little as 0-7 years (3909). The success of these programs can be dependent on continued releases to supplement the population (3914, 3909). 

Habitat management at the release site is a significant factor. Practices such as coppicing, selective felling, planting, fencing, host plant translocation, invasive plant removal, sheep grazing, and scrub clearance have been associated with the persistence and increased abundance of translocated populations (3909). For example, captive-bred pearl-bordered fritillaries released into coppiced woodland successfully bred at least once (3914). The life stage at which individuals are released varies, with releases of eggs, caterpillars, pupae, and adults all being recorded (3914). The specific conditions of the release site are also important; for instance, the survival of large blue caterpillars was higher when they were translocated into nests of the ant Myrmica sabuleti that did not have a queen present (3909). Comparative studies have found that translocated large copper caterpillars had a higher survival rate than captive-bred ones (3909), and that released, captive-bred large copper caterpillars had lower survival rates than their captive, wild, or translocated counterparts (3914). Nineteen years after translocation, a population of large blue butterflies in the UK showed similar genetic diversity to its Swedish source population (3909). Following a release of captive-bred large coppers, the number of eggs laid per female increased over the first three years (3914).

query: What are the benefits of planting new hedges and managing existing ones for butterfly and moth conservation on farmland?
relevant_summary:
Planting new hedges and managing existing ones provides numerous benefits for butterfly and moth conservation on farmland. Studies in the UK, Ireland, and Canada have shown that established hedgerows support a higher species richness of butterflies and macro-moths compared to other farm habitats like beetle banks, crops, or pastures (3976). The abundance of butterflies and moths is also greater along hedgerows than in open fields or on grass margins (3976). The composition of the hedge is important, as planting species like gorse, oak, and blackthorn can support a higher number of arthropod species, including caterpillars, than the more commonly planted hawthorn (3976).

The management of existing hedgerows also plays a crucial role. Hedgerows with a more complex structure, such as those with trees, have a higher diversity of butterflies and moths (3975). Management practices like cutting hedgerows less frequently (every 2-3 years), cutting in autumn, or allowing for incremental growth can increase the abundance of butterflies, moths, and their caterpillars (3975). The height and shape of the hedge also matter; hedgerows kept between 1-2 meters tall in Italy and those with scalloped edges in Belgium have been found to support more butterflies and their eggs (3975). Laid or coppiced hedges in the UK also had a higher abundance of butterflies than unmanaged ones (3975). Furthermore, providing training and advice to landowners about agri-environment schemes has resulted in the management of large areas of farmland for the benefit of species like the marsh fritillary butterfly (3846).

query: What are the potential benefits and negative consequences of abandoning management on grasslands for butterfly and moth populations?
relevant_summary:
Abandoning management on grasslands can have both positive and negative effects on butterfly and moth populations. 

Potential negative consequences of abandoning management include the extinction of six heath fritillary populations on unmanaged grasslands (3966). In contrast, traditional hay meadows mown once a year supported a higher abundance of heath fritillary adults and caterpillars than old, abandoned meadows (3908). Summer-grazed or mown grasslands were found to have a lower abundance of woodland butterflies and burnet moths than abandoned grasslands (3908). Additionally, after a reduction in management, the abundance of two butterfly species decreased, and 12 species of moth showed a preference for more intensively managed grasslands (3958).

Potential benefits of abandoning or reducing management intensity on grasslands include a higher species richness of butterflies and moths (3958). Less intensively managed grasslands may also support more specialist moth species, species of conservation concern, and butterfly species with specific host plant requirements (3958). Several studies found that the abundance of butterflies, micro-moths, and declining macro-moths was higher in low-input or unfertilized, ungrazed grasslands (3958). One study found that butterflies were less abundant in managed grasslands compared to unmanaged ones (3908). Similarly, unmown grasslands were found to have a higher abundance and species richness of nocturnal moths compared to mown grasslands (3908). Some species, like the small pearl-bordered fritillary, were found more frequently in abandoned meadows than in grazed ones (3908).

Some studies found no significant difference, with the species richness and community composition of butterflies and moths being similar between managed and unmanaged or less-intensively managed grasslands (3958, 3908).

query: In European forests, how do the effects of coppicing and clearing patches compare for butterfly and moth communities?
relevant_summary:
In European forests, comparing the effects of coppicing and clearing patches on butterfly and moth communities reveals varied impacts.

In terms of community composition, coppiced woodland and wider woodland rides were found to have more unique species of macro-moths than mature forest or standard width rides (3938, 3939). Different aged coppiced woodlands supported different communities of butterflies and moths (3939).

For species richness and diversity, cleared patches in forests showed a greater species richness of butterflies but a lower species richness of moths when compared to unmanaged patches, coppiced woodland, or closed-canopy forests (3938). One study noted a decline in butterfly species richness over the first three years after clearing (3938). In contrast, coppiced woodland was found to have a greater species richness of butterflies than unmanaged woodland (3939). However, it also had a lower species richness of macro-moths than mature forest, and the age of the coppice did not affect this (3939). Another study found that woodland coppiced two years prior had a greater butterfly species richness than woodland coppiced more than 15 years prior (3939). The species richness of moths was similar in woodland that was coppiced 1-4, 5-8 and 12-20 years ago (3939).

Regarding population abundance, cleared forest patches that were also coppiced and grazed had a higher abundance of butterflies in general, including species like the chequered blue, woodland brown, high brown fritillary, and small pearl-bordered fritillary, compared to unmanaged or solely coppiced areas (3938). However, the abundance of butterflies in these cleared patches declined over the first three years after clearing (3938). Larger cleared patches supported a higher abundance of butterflies than undisturbed forest (3938), while wider rides had a lower abundance of macro-moths than standard width rides or mature forest (3938). In coppiced woodlands, a higher abundance of butterflies, particularly the heath fritillary, was observed compared to unmanaged woodland (3939). Populations of pearl-bordered fritillary and small pearl-bordered fritillary were also more likely to persist in coppiced woodland (3939). Conversely, the abundance of macro-moths was lower in coppiced woodland than in mature forest, with no change in abundance based on the age of the coppice (3939). The timing of coppicing was also a factor, with higher butterfly abundance found in woodlands coppiced 2, 2-4, 5-7, or 12-15 years ago compared to those coppiced 5-11 or over 15 years ago (3939). After coppicing along with other management like scrub control and grazing, the abundance of high brown fritillary and small pearl-bordered fritillary increased (3939). Across Europe, clearing small patches in forests was reported to benefit 19 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern (3938).

query: What is the evidence for the success of re-establishing butterfly populations through translocation and captive-breeding programs?
relevant_summary:
Two of three studies on translocating butterflies and moths outside their native range reported that populations of some species persisted and increased in abundance over 8 and 28 years (3911). The third study reported that a translocated population died out within one year (3911). One study found that 69 years after translocation, an introduced butterfly population had similar genetic diversity to its source (3911). 

For captive-bred releases, six studies reported that butterfly populations persisted for 2-28 years and increased in abundance, though some required continued releases (3914). However, other studies reported populations dying out within 1-12 years or requiring further releases to survive (3914). One review found that 25% of captive-bred and translocated butterfly populations survived for more than 3 years, but 38% died out in that time (3914). One study reported that three of ten captive-bred populations established (3914). Regarding reproductive success, one study noted an increase in eggs laid per female over three years (3914), and another confirmed that released adults successfully bred at least once (3914). Conversely, three studies found that released, captive-bred caterpillars had lower survival rates than wild or translocated caterpillars (3914).

relevant_summary:
Four replicated, site comparison studies found that landscapes with smaller fields had a higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than areas with larger fields (3974). Two of four replicated, site comparison studies found that areas with smaller fields had a higher species richness of butterflies and burnet moths, while two studies found similar species richness (3974). One before-and-after study found that reducing field size, along with other habitat improvements, increased the species richness of butterflies and burnet moths (3974).

Regarding margin width, two site comparison studies found that the species richness of butterflies was higher in longer or wider uncultivated margins than in shorter, narrower or conventional width margins (3981). Similarly, five replicated, site comparison studies found that wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had a greater species richness or diversity of butterflies and moths than narrower or conventional width margins (3982). However, one replicated, controlled study found that 2-m grass margins had a greater species richness of butterflies than cropped field edges, but 6-m grass margins did not (3982). For abundance, one study found that wide uncultivated margins had a higher abundance of butterflies than conventional margins (3981). Three of seven replicated, site comparison studies found that wider grass margins (up to 6 m wide) had a higher abundance of habitat-sensitive butterflies and moths than narrower or conventional width margins (3982).

More generally, nine of eleven studies found that the species richness of butterflies and moths was higher on farms with a greater proportion of semi-natural habitat (3910). Six replicated studies also found that the abundance of butterflies and moths was higher on farms with a greater proportion of semi-natural habitat (3910). Additionally, three of four site comparison studies found that established hedgerows had a higher species richness of butterflies and macro-moths than in-field beetle banks, crops or pasture (3976), and five of six studies found that the abundance of butterflies and moths was higher along hedgerows (3976).
